column4: this is more of a nix question but you guys like a challenge right?  Is it possible to scan a directory for a certain hex value BESIDES hexdump -c * | grep ab\ cd ??????
searching for a file with a certain value in its name, or in its contents?
contents but HEX content not just text
if you can escape the hex values, you can simply use grep
I think so, there's one way to find out :)
is there any particular reason you don't want to use hexdump?
the files are piped directly into grep, so there is *very* little overhead (grep would need to open them anyways)
you may experience slightly more cpu usage, but the speed will be limited by your HDD's read speed long before the cpu chokes on it
as a command alone or as the grep search pattern?
as the grep search string. I think that's the bash escape sequence for hex
is it possible to do a wild card search?  so kinda like grep $'\xab\xcd\x(wildcard)' *   ?
sorry, replace ## by the hex code of the character you are searching for
was it a wiki page from ubuntu's website, or a 3rd party location?
